Concept_BELIEVES_IN.manifestation: The narrator believes grown-ups do not understand anything by themselves.
The narrator gave up on his dream of being a painter because grown-ups did not understand his drawings.
The little prince is surprised by the narrator's ideas about grown-ups.
The narrator talks to grown-ups about bridge, golf, and politics to be considered sensible.
The little prince asks the narrator to draw a sheep.
The little prince is not satisfied with the narrator's drawings of a sheep.
The little prince is happy with the drawing of the box, because he believes the sheep is inside.
The little prince is happy with the box because the sheep can use it as a house.
The little prince does not want to tie the sheep because he believes everything is small where he lives.
The narrator believes grown-ups only care about figures.
The narrator believes grown-ups would not understand the little prince's existence.
The narrator believes that figures are a matter of indifference.
The little prince is concerned about the baobabs.

The narrator draws the baobabs to warn children.

The little prince is disappointed that the geographer does not know about his planet.
The little prince is sad because his flower is ephemeral.
